questions.text: Which of the following EEG wave patterns is typically associated with specific states of consciousness or neurological activity in humans, and what does it correctly indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha waves (8-12 Hz) - Indicate deep sleep and unconsciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.

options.label: C
options.text: Beta waves (13-30 Hz) - Commonly associated with relaxed wakefulness and mental activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Delta waves (0.5-4 Hz) - Associated with REM sleep and alertness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.
questions.explanation:
Delta Wave

  • Seen in slow wave deep sleep or delta sleep. (Option D)
  • Also seen in infants.
  • Frequency: 0.5-3 Hz.
  • Amplitude or the micro voltage- High, ≥75 V.

Theta waves

  • The transition from wakefulness to sleep.
  • 1st wave that is encountered in sleep.
  • Also seen in children.
  • Frequency: 4-7 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Prominently seen in the temporal and parietal regions.

Alpha Waves

  • Seen at rest - When the person is awake but the eyes are closed. (Option A)
  • Frequency: 8-13Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Seen in occipital and parieto-occipital areas.

Beta Wave

  • Seen in a fully awake person (eyes open). (Option C)
  • Frequency: Higher, 14-30 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Present in the frontal and parietal areas.

Gamma wave
  • High-frequency brain activity.
  • Frequencies between 30-100 Hz.
  • Prominent during REM sleep.
  • Contribute to the consolidation of memories and processing of information.

questions.text: Examine the given EEG, EOG, and EMG recordings. Which of the following statements best describes the physiological characteristics based on these recordings?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG shows high amplitude, low-frequency waves; EOG shows minimal eye movement; EMG shows high muscle tone.

options.label: B
options.text: EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves; EOG shows rapid eye movements; EMG shows atonia (reduced muscle tone).

options.label: C
options.text: EEG shows slow waves; EOG shows no eye movement; EMG shows regular muscle contractions.

options.label: D
options.text: EEG shows spikes and waves; EOG shows slow rolling eye movements; EMG shows normal muscle tone

questions.correct_answer: B. EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves; EOG shows rapid eye movements; EMG shows atonia (reduced muscle tone).

questions.text: What does a sleep stage histogram typically represent in sleep studies, and which of the following best describes its key components?

options.label: A
options.text: The frequency of waking episodes throughout the night and their duration.

options.label: B
options.text: The distribution of sleep stages (NREM and REM) over the course of the night and the amount of time spent in each stage.

options.label: C
options.text: The average heart rate during each hour of sleep shows changes in cardiac activity.

options.label: D
options.text: The brainwave activity is measured in Hertz (Hz) across different sleep stages, illustrating neurological patterns.

questions.correct_answer: B. The distribution of sleep stages (NREM and REM) over the course of the night and the amount of time spent in each stage.

questions.text: A sleep study reveals that a patient experiences increased muscle tone and vivid dreaming. Based on this finding, which of the following statements best differentiates REM sleep from NREM sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: REM sleep is associated with increased muscle tone, while NREM sleep features muscle atonia.

options.label: B
options.text: REM sleep is associated with muscle atonia, whereas NREM sleep features increased muscle tone.

options.label: C
options.text: REM sleep occurs only in the early hours of the night, while NREM sleep predominates throughout the night .

options.label: D
options.text: REM sleep is marked by delta waves, while NREM sleep is marked by alpha waves.

questions.correct_answer: B. REM sleep is associated with muscle atonia, whereas NREM sleep features increased muscle tone.
questions.explanation:
REM

NREM
  • Paradoxical sleep- asleep but the EEG is showing the activity of the active day.
  • Brain activity and physiological activity area increased or same as in the awake state except for the muscle tone (the muscles are in the state of paralysis).
  • Known as desynchronized sleep: Lots of variables in REM
  • Body movements are absent.
  • Penile erection is present.
  • Dreams are remembered.

Disorders:

  1. Narcolepsy
  2. Nightmares
  3. REM sleep behavior disorder
  4. Sleep apnea
  • Known as orthodox or conventional sleep
  • Brain activity & physiological activity are lower than in the awake state.
  • Known as synchronized- minimal variations are there in parameters such as pulse rate, respiratory rate, and BP.
  • Pulsatile release of Gonadotropins and Growth hormones.
  • Body movements are present.
  • Penile erection is absent.
  • Dreams are not remembered.

Disorders:

  1. Somnambulism (sleepwalking)
  2. Night terror
  3. Bruxism
  4. Nocturnal enuresis
  5. Somniloquy (sleep talking)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings for the past six months. He reports feeling fatigued during the day but denies any history of substance use, psychiatric illness, or significant stressors. His physical examination and laboratory tests are unremarkable. He has tried over-the-counter sleep aids with little effect. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of difficulty falling asleep and frequent nocturnal awakenings. She describes an uncomfortable sensation in her legs, often accompanied by an irresistible urge to move them, particularly in the evening and at night. These symptoms subside temporarily after moving her legs but recur shortly after. She denies any history of substance use, and her medical history is unremarkable. What is the most likely cause of her insomnia?

A 25-year-old male presents with excessive daytime sleepiness for the past six months. He describes episodes where he suddenly loses muscle tone and falls to the ground after laughing. These episodes increase in situations when he becomes very emotional. He also reports experiencing vivid, dream-like hallucinations upon waking and occasional paralysis on waking from sleep. Based on the clinical picture, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with narcolepsy after presenting with excessive daytime sleepiness and episodes of cataplexy triggered by laughter. She also experiences sleep paralysis and hypnagogic hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for her excessive daytime sleepiness?

A 19-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of excessive sleep lasting for several days to weeks. His parents report that during these episodes, he sleeps for 18-20 hours a day, is difficult to wake and when awake, he exhibits irritability, hyperphagia, and hypersexual behavior. Between episodes, he returns to his normal baseline functioning without any neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Atypical Features

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a sleep clinic with episodes of walking around her house at night while appearing to be asleep. She performs complex tasks, sometimes injuring herself, and has no recollection of these activities in the morning. Her doctor notes she experiences heightened stress and occasional sleep deprivation. Which of the following is NOT classified as an NREM-related parasomnia?
questions.explanation:
NREM related Parasomnias

Sleepwalking (Somnambulism)
  • Involves walking or engaging in complex behaviors while in a state of unconsciousness, which may lead to injuries or dangerous situations.
  • Typically occurs during slow-wave sleep, starting in the first or second slow-wave episodes.
  • Can be triggered by sleep deprivation and disruption of slow-wave sleep..
  • Difficult to awaken; they often appear confused when roused.
  • More common in children, with a peak prevalence between ages 4 and 8, and usually resolves by adolescence.
  • Can occur as a primary disorder or secondary to another sleep issue, like sleep apnea.

Night Terrors
  • Night terrors involve sudden arousal with intense fear, often starting with a scream.
  • Accompanied by signs of severe anxiety and confusion; individuals are unresponsive to stimuli.
  • Typically occurs during slow-wave sleep and may be triggered by fever or CNS depressant withdrawal.
  • Amnesia for the episode is common.
  • Unlike nightmares, sleep terrors may lack detailed imagery.

Confusional Arousals
  • Defined as a milder form of NREM sleep parasomnia, often seen in children.
  • Involves partial awakening, confusion, and then returning to sleep.
  • Believed to be on a continuum with sleepwalking and sleep terrors.

Sleep-Related Eating Disorder

  
  • Classified under NREM sleep arousal disorders, specifically as “sleepwalking with sleep-related eating.”
  • Involves episodes of eating during sleep, often with no awareness of the behavior.
  • Can lead to weight gain and health issues, including injuries while preparing food.

Sleep Talking (Somniloquy)
  • Speaking during sleep without awareness is often incoherent or nonsensical.
  • Occurs during stages N1 and N2, but can also happen in REM.
  • Can vary from rare occurrences to frequent episodes, lasting for a few seconds or minutes.
  • Can occur independently or alongside other parasomnias like sleepwalking or night terrors.
  • Stress, sleep deprivation, alcohol, or fever may trigger episodes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner, who reports that he frequently acts out his dreams during sleep. She describes him kicking, punching, and even shouting while asleep, often appearing very distressed. He has no recollection of these events upon waking and has no history of sleepwalking. His partner expresses concern about the risk of injury to both of them during these episodes. On polysomnography, REM sleep without atonia was seen. Which condition is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
REM related Parasomnias

Nightmare Disorder

(Option A ruled out)
  • Nightmares are frightening dreams that wake the person sleeping.
  • They are often remembered.
  • Common in children (ages 3-6) but rare in adults.
  • Can lead to insomnia due to fear of sleeping.
  • Associated with PTSD and traumatic events.
  • Certain medications and substance abuse can trigger nightmares.
  • Treatment:
    • Behavioral techniques like desensitization, exposure therapy, image rehearsal therapy, and cognitive therapy can be effective.
    • Medications such as prazosin, nitrazepam, and triazolam may also help, especially for PTSD-related nightmares.

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)
  • RBD involves acting out dreams due to lack of sleep paralysis.
  • Individuals may punch or kick while dreaming.
  • They are unaware of their surroundings during episodes.
  • Actions relate directly to dream content.
  • There is a risk of injury to themselves or others.
  • Various drugs and conditions can worsen RBD.
  • On polysomnography, REM sleep without atonia may be seen.
  • May be associated with DLB, Parkinson's disease.

Recurrent Isolated Sleep Paralysis

(Option C ruled out)
  • Sleep paralysis is the inability to move during sleep onset or awakening.
  • It can be distressing and may include hallucinations.
  • It can occur independently of narcolepsy.
  • Paralysis can last from one to several minutes.
  • Risk factors include irregular sleep, stress, and sleep deprivation.
  • Treatment:
    • Improved sleep hygiene and ensuring sufficient sleep are primary treatments.
    • Rapid eye movements or being touched may help terminate episodes.
